i mean jeps are an interesting idea because you know java is is a platform that as
rory said you know there's millions of developers who use java so what you don't want is to suddenly make lots of
changes to it in a way that affects things like backwards compatibility and
you know makes it harder for developers so the the idea is that you have to be very careful
in terms of the changes that you make and that means that when jets are proposed
you have to have a good sort of idea of what's actually going to happen and it
has to be done in a way that the rest of the open jdk community community can
look at it and say yes that actually makes sense so we went through the whole process of
i think we were the first company to actually add a jep um other than oracle to the jdk and we literally added one
method to the the run class and uh or runable class and it was no
thread class sorry thread class and the the amount of work that involved was
really quite substantial but that was good because you don't want people adding methods to
thread or runnable or you know core classes and just saying oh i think this is a good idea let's put it in there and
see what happens so we had to go through a number of steps to make that work and
really the thing with jeps as monica said is you need to demonstrate that this will work so you actually have to
come with code not just an idea come with code come with a proof of concept make sure that it all works and you can
demonstrate it and then prove to people that that will actually work and can be
taken into the open jdk as a whole so it's a nice process it's um it works
well in terms of keeping java moving forward but not in a way that people can just throw ideas in
